articles.title: Chinese EV makers from Leapmotor to Zeekr challenge Tesla in premium segment
articles.content: Chinese EV makers from Leapmotor to Zeekr challenge Tesla in premium segment South China Morning Post October 17, 2025 4 min read In this article: 9863.HK TSLA ZK STLAM.MI Chinese electric-vehicle (EV) makers are raising the game in the premium segment by launching more spacious and longer-range models to challenge Tesla , which has been steadily losing market share on the mainland. Stellantis-backed Leapmotor has become the latest to join the fray against Elon Musk's Tesla, with founder and CEO Zhu Jiangming describing its decision to move up the value chain as a mission to offer consumers the best EVs at the best prices. "Leapmotor is able to launch higher-end and more sophisticated models at affordable prices, which will prove to be a value-for-money proposition for all customers," he said at an event in Shanghai on Thursday to unveil the D19 luxury SUV. "We have been fine-tuning our technologies and improving our capabilities for years." Do you have questions about the biggest topics and trends from around the world? Get the answers with SCMP Knowledge , our new platform of curated content with explainers, FAQs, analyses and infographics brought to you by our award-winning team. Hangzhou-based Leapmotor, 20 per cent owned by Stellantis, formerly Fiat Chrysler, has consistently racked up high sales this year in the highly competitive EV sector, as its low-priced intelligent models have been well received by young and middle-income consumers. An EV chassis is displayed at Leapmotor's event to unveil the D19 SUV in Shanghai on Thursday. Photo: Daniel Ren alt=An EV chassis is displayed at Leapmotor's event to unveil the D19 SUV in Shanghai on Thursday. Photo: Daniel Ren> The luxury SUV, which features extended-range battery technology, is the 10-year-old company's first vehicle in the premium segment. Extended-range electric vehicles, known as EREVs, use a small internal combustion engine to generate additional power to charge the battery when needed. Leapmotor's D19 EREV is fitted with an 80 kilowatt-hour (kWh) battery pack, the largest ever in an electric car of its kind, offering a 500km range before switching to hybrid mode. Tesla's new six-seat pure electric Model Y L assembled at its Gigafactory in Shanghai is powered by an 82kWh battery pack giving it a range of 751km on a single charge. The US carmaker began delivering the Model Y variant last month. "Chinese-designed EVs are mounting a challenge to Tesla with models featuring bigger batteries and more sophisticated digital technologies," said Eric Han, a senior manager at Suolei, an ­advisory firm in Shanghai. "They will take time to build their brands' reputation to convince global customers of their quality and performance." La historia continúa Hong Kong-listed Leapmotor delivered 66,657 units in September, up 102 per cent from a year earlier and an increase of 30 per cent from August, rewriting its sales record for the fifth consecutive month. It delivered 395,516 vehicles between January and September, a 129 per cent jump from the same period in 2024. In July, Leapmotor launched a midsize sedan that offers similar features to Tesla's Model 3 at less than half the price. The B01, priced from 89,800 yuan on the mainland, would be sold globally as it pursued growth amid cutthroat competition at home, Zhu said at the time. The CEO said on Thursday that the D19 SUV used components from world-class suppliers like Contemporary Amperex Technology, the world's largest EV battery producer , and ZF Group, a German chassis maker. Leapmotor has yet to disclose prices for the D19, which is also available in pure electric variants. The basic edition of Tesla's Model Y L carries a price tag of 339,000 yuan (US$47,580), compared with 263,500 yuan for the older entry-level model. Analysts expected Leapmotor's D19 to start at about 300,000 yuan. Voyah, an EV unit of state-owned Dongfeng Motor, began taking pre-orders for its flagship SUV, the Taishan, last month. Powered by a 65kWh battery pack and a full tank of petrol, the hybrid SUV can go as far as 1,400km. The battery alone offers a range of up to 370km. Voyah has not announced prices for the Taishan either. In late September, Zeekr, a premium EV subsidiary of Geely Auto , mainland China's second-largest carmaker, began selling its luxury hybrid SUV 9X, whose variants are equipped with 55kWh and 70kWh battery packs, offering a driving range of 300km to 380km when fully charged. Its superfast charging battery technology gives a car a range of more than 200km with just 10 minutes of charging. Tesla commanded a 16 per cent share of the Chinese EV market in 2020 when its Shanghai Gigafactory began producing Model 3 vehicles for mainland customers. That slumped to 6.9 per cent last year due to rising challenges from domestic firms. articles.content: Tesla, Nvidia, Rigetti, Praxis: Trending Stocks Ramzan Karmali October 17, 2025 In this video: PRAX RGTI RGTIW TSLA NVDA Tesla ( TSLA ) continued its slide in the pre-market on another bearish analyst report, and mounting questions around Elon Musk company's ability to deliver on robotics and AI promises. Nvidia ( NVDA ) shares swing down then recover some ground ahead of the open. Meta ( META ) is close to a $30 billion financing deal for a data center in Louisiana, and shares of its AI glasses partner EssilorLuxottica ( EL.PA ) hit a new record. Micron ( MU ) abandons some of its chip supplying activities in China. Other top gainers and losers include Praxis ( PRAX ) and Rigetti ( RGTI ). For more live coverage of markets watch the full episode of Market Sunrise and head to Yahoo Finance . Video Transcript 00:09 Speaker A It's time now for today's trending tickers. We start with Tesla, which is continuing to fall in the pre-market after a tough session yesterday. 00:20 Speaker A Sentiment among investors is mixed to say the least, following another bearing report from analysts at BNP Pariba yesterday, even as Tesla sold more cars last quarter, as people were rushing to take advantage of the expiring tax credit. 00:32 Speaker A Tesla's valuation is based on Elon Musk's big promises for robots and AI, and for now, those promises still haven't materialized into anything concrete. 00:43 Speaker A Next up, Nvidia, and this will be seen as a key indicator for the whole stock market today to see if fears around regional banks spill into the pillars of the AI boom. 00:54 Speaker A The world's largest company has shown strong performance in recent weeks despite headwinds from geopolitical tensions, but it's dropped more than two and a half 1. 1.3% overnight. And of course, whatever happens to Nvidia today, will have an outsized impact on the rest of the stock market. 01:07 Speaker A Now, let's look at another tech giant, Meta. It's also in the red, and this follows the news from Bloomberg that Meta is close to clinching a $30 billion financing deal for a giant data center in Central Louisiana. 01:21 Speaker A That huge funding may come from Morgan Stanley. And this morning, with everything that's happening with banks, some investors might be worried about the massive size of this project, which also involves Blue Owl Capital. 01:32 Speaker A On the other hand, a key partner of Meta is hitting new record highs. Today in Paris, SLOR Luxottico, the world's leading maker of glasses, posted a sales beat driven by the success of Meta's AI smart glasses. 01:45 Speaker A And if you've been following AI news, you will be interested in Micron. Shares in the US chipmaker were in the red in pre-market trading after Reuters reported that the US chipmaker plans to cease supplying server chips to data centers in China following a prolonged business slump linked to a 2023 government ban. 02:03 Speaker A China accounted for around 12% of Micron's total revenue in the last fiscal year. 02:08 Speaker A Okay, let's move on to Quantum computing now. very briefly, the key thing you need to know is that Ragetti, which has been driven by speculation around quantum computers, is in free fall in the pre-market after it already lost nearly 15% in yesterday's session. 02:22 Speaker A Investors are worried about weak fundamentals. 02:26 Speaker A And before we go, write down this name. It's a stock that's almost tripled in value in the past 24 hours. Praxis precision medicines was the number one trending ticker on Yahoo Finance this Friday morning after the clinical stage bio phaceutical company unveiled plans to raise more than $500 million through a public share offering. articles.title: Tesla Stock At A Make-Or-Break Point (Rating Downgrade)
Buy Now, Pay Later and 6 More Ways You Can Finance a Tesla in 2025
articles.content: Buy Now, Pay Later and 6 More Ways You Can Finance a Tesla in 2025 ©Tesla Motors Sean Bryant October 18, 2025 3 min read In this article: TSLA KLAR So, you’re thinking about buying a Tesla this year. That’s exciting, and a little overwhelming, depending on your budget . Let’s get real for a second. Unless you’re paying outright in cash, the real question becomes how you’re going to finance it without stretching yourself too thin. The good news? There are options. A lot more than you might think. Keep reading as we look at six different ways you can pay for your new Tesla purchase ( beyond using buy now, pay later ). Check Out: What Does It Cost To Charge a Tesla Monthly Compared to Gas for a Honda CR-V? Read Next: 6 Hybrid Vehicles To Stay Away From in Retirement You Can Use Klarna, but With Limits You won’t be financing your actual car through Klarna, but you can split things like wall chargers or floor mats into four smaller payments. Tesla partnered with Klarna for shop items, not vehicles, and it’s interest-free for six weeks. It’s not flashy, but it helps when you’re staring down all the extras. Tesla’s Built-In Financing Tool Is Simple If you would prefer to avoid third-party lenders, you can apply for financing directly through Tesla when you order your car. They’ll walk you through everything online. You’ll get loan terms between 36 and 84 months, and you can even roll in things like Full Self-Driving. It’s not always the lowest rate, but it’s fast and easy. Learn More: The Surprising Reason Retirees Shouldn’t Pay Cash for a Car Credit Unions Still Come Out Ahead Sometimes Don’t sleep on your credit union . Most of the time, they’ll beat the annual percentage rate (APR) you’ll be offered by Tesla. This means it might be worth the extra steps if you want to save over the long term. You’ll need to apply and get pre-approved before placing your order, but people who’ve done it swear it’s worth it. Leasing Isn’t Dead When leasing a Tesla, you’ll likely receive a lower monthly payment than if you purchased, but it comes with a mileage limit and no ownership at the end of the lease. This makes sense if you don’t drive many miles or want the option to upgrade after a couple of years. Some People Just Pay Upfront If you’re sitting on enough cash to pay outright, Tesla takes wires and ACH transfers. That means no loan, no monthly payments and most importantly, no interest. This is the lowest total cost option if you’re planning to keep the car for a while. Home Equity Option A few folks take out a home equity line of credit (HELOC) to fund their Tesla. Rates can be lower than a car loan, but your house is collateral. Only do this if you’re comfortable with the risk and know you’ll be able to make the payments. Story Continues Personal Loans Are Still Available Personal loans aren’t tied to the car, so they’re a little riskier for lenders, and they’ll charge you for that. Interest rates are almost higher for personal loans than they are for auto loans, but it might be your best shot if you’re struggling to get a loan from an auto lender. So, What’s Your Move? If your goal is a low monthly payment, you might want to choose leasing. But if you would prefer to minimize your overall cost, you’re better off paying cash or using a low-cost auto loan. While Tesla’s own financing is an option, your local credit union will most likely offer a better interest rate. No matter how you plan to finance your new Tesla, just make sure the payment plan fits within your budget. articles.title: Tesla Q3 EPS Preview: Momentum Meets Uncertainty
articles.content: Tesla Q3 EPS Preview: Momentum Meets Uncertainty Andrew Rocco Sun, October 19, 2025 at 7:34 PM EDT 3 min read In this article: TSLA Tesla Earnings Are Due Wednesday Zacks Rank #3 (Hold) stock Tesla ( TSLA ), the worldwide electric vehicle (EV) leader and a dynamic technology innovator, will report third-quarter 2025 earnings after the market close on Wednesday, October 22 nd . Though Tesla has been one of the top-performing stocks since its IPO in July 2010 (with a 34,000% return), the stock has taken investors on a wild ride over the past few years. Namely, Tesla has had to weather new tariff policies, a slowing EV market, higher interest rates, and increased competition. Additionally, Tesla and its iconic but controversial CEO, Elon Musk, have faced intense political backlash from both sides of the political aisle. Despite its many challenges, TSLA shares are up a robust 93% over the past six months. Zacks Investment Research Image Source: Zacks Investment Research Tesla EPS Preview Below are some key details to know ahead of Tesla’s earnings: Tesla Consensus Analyst Estimates Zacks Consensus Estimates suggest tepid sales growth and negative EPS growth until 2026. Wall Street expects Q3 revenue of $26.45B (+5.05%), with EPS of $0.53 (-26.39%). Zacks Investment Research Image Source: Zacks Investment Research Tesla EPS Surprise History Tesla has delivered spotty earnings results recently. Despite tempered Tesla analyst expectations, Tesla has missed expectations in six of the past ten quarters. Zacks Investment Research Image Source: Zacks Investment Research Meanwhile, Tesla has missed analyst expectations by an average of 3.65% over the past four quarters. Zacks Investment Research Image Source: Zacks Investment Research TSLA Expected Move The options market implies a potential move of +/- $37.48 or an 8.53% implied move. Tesla has had an average move of +/- 10.53% over the past eight quarters. TSLA shares have been higher the day after EPS 50% of the time over that time. TSLA Technical View After breaking out from a low-level base structure in September, TSLA shares are coiling in a classic bull flag pattern. If Tesla exceeds expectations, the stock should make a run at its previous all-time high of $488. Should TSLA miss expectations, the stock is likely to test the confluence of the open price gap and rising 50-day moving average ~$400. Zacks Investment Research Image Source: TradingView Tesla EPS: 3 Key Catalysts Tesla’s post-earnings price action will likely be determined by the answer to three critical questions, including: 1. Has Tesla’s Legacy EV Business Bottomed? Tesla recently produced and announced a record number of vehicle deliveries. However, investors will be listening closely to see what Elon Musk and his team have to say about forward expectations in the wake of the removal of federal EV tax credits, lower interest rates, and the new ‘Model Y’ sales performance. Story continues 2. Will Energy Segment Growth Continue? In the absence of a growing EV business, Tesla Energy has been a bastion of growth. Last year, the segment grew at a robust 67%. Meanwhile, thus far in 2025, energy storage deployments have increased at a triple-digit pace. With the AI boom in full force, Tesla’s energy storage business should benefit as energy-hungry data centers require energy storage solutions like Tesla’s ‘Megapack.’ 3. Will Tesla Meet Timelines for FSD, Robotaxis, and Optimus? Elon Musk is well-known for his aggressive timelines for new products. However, if Musk can convince investors that future product roadmaps are still on track, investors will reward him. Bottom Line As Tesla prepares to report Q3 earnings, investors face a familiar mix of excitement and uncertainty. With the stock surging nearly 93% in the past six months, expectations are high – yet tempered by Tesla’s recent mixed track record. Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research?
